title: Powerlifting and Steroid Use
content: Mark and Chris Bell discuss their love of powerlifting, their unbelievable personal records, and what prompted the making of their now iconic film, Bigger, Stronger, Faster. They also very openly discuss steroid use.

title: Addiction and Helping Others
content: Chris’s personal story of addiction and how he’s using his experience to help others. Importance of sharing your struggle, and the danger of comparing yourself to others.

title: Weight Lifting and Motivation
content: How they got started lifting weights, powerlifting vs Olympic lifting, and personal records. Lifting weights: the importance of challenging yourself, how to avoid injury, monitoring progress, and staying motivated.

title: Diet and Performance
content: Chris on how changing his diet changed his performance and life. Best resources for those wanting to get started lifting weights effectively and safely.

title: Strength Training and Sedentary Lifestyle
content: Teaching kids strength training early in life, the negative impact of sitting and how we can minimize it.

title: Bodybuilding and Ketogenic Diet
content: Benefits of bodybuilding, Mark’s prep for his first competition, and the role of the ketogenic diet.

title: Steroid Controversy and Testosterone
content: The steroid controversy: Mark’s use of them and Peter’s perspective. Testosterone: Peter’s approach to improving it in patients, and the impact of sleep, cortisol, and statins on production.

title: Kratom and Opioid Addiction
content: Kratom, a powerful plant with the potential to help opioid addiction and more.

title: Optimizing Brain Health
content: Alzheimer's disease risk factors, APOE, prevention strategies, and more.

title: Training Principles for Longevity
content: Training principles for longevity.

title: Preventing Cardiovascular Disease
content: The latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more.

title: Pros and Cons of GLP-1 Weight Loss Drugs and Metformin
content: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent.

title: Overcoming Trauma and Finding Inner Peace
content: Overcoming trauma, finding inner peace, and living a meaningful and fulfilling life.

title: The History of the Cell and Cell Therapy
content: The history of the cell, cell therapy, gene therapy, and more.

title: The Impact of Steroids
content: The impact of Bigger, Stronger, Faster, how it got made, and how it challenged Peter’s set of beliefs regarding steroids.

title: Personal Story of Addiction and Recovery
content: Chris’s personal story of addiction and how he’s using his experience to help others.

title: Importance of Physical Activity
content: Importance of surrounding yourself with a support group. Chris’s goal is to simply help people lead a healthier lifestyle, physically and mentally. Mark and Chris say their first prescription for everyone who is struggling is simply to get up and start moving, even if it’s just a 10-minute walk, just start.

title: Sharing Your Struggle and Avoiding Comparison
content: Sharing your struggle can have an amazing impact on others because feeling alone can lead people to dark places. It’s important to communicate this vulnerability about your own struggle. It’s easy to judge someone else when you don’t know where they started. Everyone has a different starting point which makes an enormous difference on where they currently stand. The bottom line is you should only look at your own progress, not other’s endpoints.

title: Starting Weightlifting and Personal Records
content: They first witnessed the raw strength of their older brother who was squatting 400 lbs at age 16. In 10th grade, Chris had bone spurs in his knees and needed surgery. His chiropractor/strength coach said you need to learn to squat to help your knees. Started with broomstick learning to squat properly. Slowly moved up in weight and 6 months later squatting 315 lbs for 8 reps. Ended up squatting over 500 lbs while still in high school. Chris was squatting 675 by 19 years old.

title: Steroid Use in High School
content: Steroid use at their high school was pretty rampant. Chris, who was against steroids back in the day, would wear a weightlifting belt with “Roids Suck” written across it. This would piss people off since most of them were on steroids, yet Chris was still stronger than them.

title: Olympic Lifting vs. Powerlifting
content: Olympic lifting consists of 2 lifts, the snatch, and the clean and jerk. Powerlifting consists of 3 lifts, squat, bench, deadlift in that order. Powerlifting is hard because it’s hard to have leverage on each of those lifts. Olympic lifting is more about being more mobile and athletic around the weight.

title: Importance of Challenging Yourself and Avoiding Injury
content: Peter’s life revolves around getting his lifting in. Especially the main lifts like squat, bench, deadlift. Peter’s #1 rule: Don’t get hurt. Mark agrees about the importance of safety, but if you are a young person first starting out, he would change the order: Rule #1: Challenge yourself. Rule #2: Don’t get hurt. Important note: As you age, you might want to reverse that order.

title: Importance of Warming Up to Avoid Injury
content: Peter says, “One of the most important realizations of my life was you can’t squat or deadlift until your glute med, your TFL, are working”. Mark adds that at a minimum, you have to move around. For upper body get the elbow and shoulder warm. For lower body, walk forward, backward, side to side, do some hip hinging, etc.

title: Challenging Yourself to Make Progress
content: The more you grow in fitness, the harder it becomes to continue to make progress. But you have to find a way because to challenge yourself because, “Without progress…I don’t believe you can even have happiness,” says Mark.

title: Changing Diet to Improve Performance
content: “The number one thing for me that really changed my life altogether is my diet. . .what I put in my mouth affected what I did in the gym”. When he was younger he would just eat like crazy and lift heavy. Chris had never been able to lose weight until he explored the ketogenic diet. He recently got back into the ketogenic/carnivore diet in the last couple of years.

title: Best Resources for Starting Weightlifting
content: Peter likes to recommend Mark Rippetoe for those needing instruction for strength training. Mark’s YouTube channel: Mark Bell – Sling Shot has over 3,000 videos including instructional videos. CrossFit is a great place to start. Powerlifting will help improve your fitness in many different sports.

title: Teaching Kids Strength Training Early in Life
content: “I would love it if each of my kids at least spends some time powerlifting because whatever you go to do later in life you will have correctly learned the mechanics of the most important movements in the human body,” says Peter.

title: Importance of Physical Education and Exercise
content: We are born with the ability to hip hinge and we lose it over time. Sitting is the thing that cripples us. We can minimize this negative impact on kids with standing desks in school and teaching kids the types of exercises to do. There should be more of an emphasis on a “real” physical education in schools.

title: Benefits of Bodybuilding and Ketogenic Diet
content: You can see rapid changes with bodybuilding. Bodybuilders have done things in very specific ways and it works time and time again. The discipline you develop from sticking to a bodybuilding regimen is a powerful trait to have. The ketogenic diet has always worked well for me because it’s allowed me to keep control over the amount of food that I eat. It’s one of the few things that has burned off my hunger. It’s one of the few things that have burned off my cravings.

title: Bodybuilding Diet
content: Mark’s diet for his upcoming competition includes 7 meals per day with 350 g protein (50 g protein per meal), 150 g carbs, 65 g fat. The average person eats 15 times per day (due to all the snacking). You can actually handle eating a lot less than you’re currently eating is one thing to know and you can actually handle a lot more training.

title: Protein Intake for Muscle Growth
content: When he increased his protein intake he saw major changes. You need 1.7 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight to elicit muscle growth. For bodybuilders, it’s important to get protein in at every meal (as opposed to all of it in one meal), because presumably amino acids have a relatively short residence and you’ve got to keep the exposure high to get the muscular hypertrophy.

title: Steroids in Bodybuilding
content: Steroids allow people to gain more weight. Steroids don’t multiply on top of themselves. They only work to a certain level. Steroids alone do not produce the type of results you see in professional bodybuilders. Steroids are still very much a part of the sport. The problem is when people abuse them and don’t understand how to use them properly or within physiologic levels.

title: Improving Testosterone Levels
content: The purpose of increasing testosterone (endogenously or exogenously) is to resolve insulin resistance and preserve muscle mass. There are actually nine steps in understanding someone’s testosterone and free testosterone level and we can actually impact every single one of those steps pharmacologically. Sleep deprivation and high cortisol levels can affect testosterone production. Statins do not inhibit endogenous testosterone production.

title: Walking for Health
content: Encouragement to start walking as a simple form of exercise. Suggestion to go for a 10-minute walk every day, preferably more than once a day. Walking is a great way to clear your mind.

title: Kratom for Opioid Addiction and Pain Relief
content: Discussion about the kratom plant and its potential benefits, including helping people get off opioids and relieving pain. Development of a product using kratom called Mind Bullet, used as a pain reliever and pre-workout supplement.

title: Fitness Information Resources
content: Investment in a YouTube channel to provide people with fitness information. Mention of a gym in Sacramento that is free for those willing to work hard.
